respStmt.orgName: The University of Texas at Austin

availability.p: The audio of Jackson Mac Low's reading is used here with permission from PennSound. The text of Mac Low's essay, "Reading a Selection from Tender Buttons," is used with permission from Charles Bernstein.

note.p: This edition combines "A CARAFE THAT IS A BLIND GLASS," the first section of Gertrude Stein's Tender Buttons, originally published in 1914, with an essay on the section by Jackson Mac Low, published in Language No. 6 and audio of Mac Low reading the poem in Charles Bernstein's poetry seminar in 1990. It is intended as a demonstration of the Versioning Machine 5.0's audio alignment features.

msIdentifier.repository: "A CARAFE, THAT IS A BLIND GLASS" is transcribed from the 1914 Marie Claire edition of Tender Buttons. "Reading a Selection from Tender Buttons" is transcribed from Language no. 6, and the audio of Jackson Mac Low is housed by and used with permission from PennSound.

Ordinarily a carafe is one of the least

—that is, the most transparent-of glass containers. It usually contains plain water. The OED defines it as "a glass water-bottle for the table, bedroom, etc." Its Romance forms (F. carafe, It. caraffa, Neapol. carrafa (a measure of liquids), Sp. & Pg. garrafa, Sicil. carabba) are related by some authorities to the Pers. garabah, a large flagon, & the Arabic gharafa, to draw or lift water.
Why, then, is this carafe a blind glass?
Is the whole poem then a
to the implied darkness & opacity of blindness, a movement condensed & made explicit in the title?
